title-group.article-title: Determination of protective role of selenium against aflatoxin B1-induced DNA damage

article-meta.aff: 3Department of Biology, Mus Alparslan University, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Sedat Bozari, Department of Biology, Mus Alparslan University, Mus, Turkey. Email: sedatbozari@gmail.com

abstract.p: Selenium is an essential mineral for a healthy life. Appropriate doses of it may undertake a protective role in the organism. In this study, the protective role of selenium (Se4+) against aflatoxin B1 (AFB1)-induced DNA damage was determined using random amplified polymorphic DNA on two plants including Vicia faba and Zea mays. It was observed that the concentrations of 0.1, 0.2 and 0.4 ppm of AFB1 have increased polymorphism value, total chlorophyll inhibition rate (IRc, %) and total protein IR (IRp, %). Unlike protein, chlorophyll contents and genomic template stability were decreased. With the addition of different concentrations (0.8 and 80 ppm) of Se4+ to the treated samples with AFB1, the values return to normal. An 800-ppm concentration of Se4+, on the contrary, could not inhibit the toxicity of AFB1 but caused an increase in toxicity level of AFB1/enhanced the toxicity level of AFB1. Results suggested that Se4+ has an antagonistic effect against AFB1 toxicity and that the degree of antagonistic effect of Se4+ against AFB1 was related to its concentration.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Mycotoxins are secondary metabolites produced by several fungi and molds (Wogan, 1975). These fungal metabolites contain different types of aflatoxins such as aflatoxin B1 (AFB1), aflatoxin G1, aflatoxin G2a, aflatoxin M1a, aflatoxin M2a, aflatoxin P1 and aflatoxin Q1a (Dalezios et al., 1971; Hartley et al., 1963; Holzapfel et al., 1966; Masri et al., 1974). AFB1 is the most existing form among these substances and also the most toxic one. This toxic substance has been shown to be a potent carcinogen, teratogen and hepatotoxin in animal (Neal, 1987; Nixon et al., 1981). These effects of AFB1 have been related to its pro-oxidant (reactive oxygen species) potential and brought about metabolic conversion of AFB1 into AFB1-8,9-epoxide, which can bind to DNA, RNA and proteins and form respective adducts (Bedard and Massey, 2006; Jeffrey, 2004).

Previous articles about the effect of AFB1 on higher plants indicated that it affects amino acid uptake, chlorophyll synthesis, germination of seeds, elongation of some plant roots and stems, protein synthesis, total carbohydrate and lipid content, RNA synthesis, chromosomal aberrations and the fidelity of DNA (Jones et al., 1980; Tripathi and Misra, 1981). Recently, several factors present in the foods of common consumption have been shown to modify these critical reactions of AFB1 in animal (Bhattacharya et al., 1984). These factors are vitamins, trace metals, fatty acids, flavonoids, phenolic acids and selenium (Francis et al., 1988).

Several studies have demonstrated that selenium provides a protective effect against the toxicity of AFB1 in animal species and plants. It was reported that selenium supplementation up to a dietary level (1.00 ppm) progressively reduced the acute toxicity of AFB1 in rat, while greater levels increased the mortality. According to Agar and Alpsoy (2005), there was an antagonistic effect of selenium against AFB1-induced chromosomal aberrations in root cells of crop plants, which was related to the treated concentration. However, so far there is no report about the protective effect of selenium against AFB1-induced metabolic activities and DNA mutation in plants. In this study, we investigate the effect of AFB1 on total protein, chlorophyll content and DNA variation by random amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD) analysis and whether selenium has a protective effect on these parameters.

sec.title: Chemicals and plant material
sec.p: AFB1 and sodium selenite were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (Taufkirchen, Germany). Seeds of Vicia faba and Zea mays were obtained from the Department of Field Crops, Faculty of Agriculture, Atatürk University (Erzurum, Turkey).

sec.title: Seed germination and applying of chemicals
sec.p: V. faba and Z. mays seeds of equal size were sterilized with 2.5% (w/v) of NaOCl for 3 min. Then the seeds were rinsed with distilled water for three to five times and dried with sterile filter paper. The seeds were soaked in sterile distilled water for 1 h, and then 15 seeds were germinated in 15 cm diameter Petri dishes on four layers of sterile Whatman number 1 filter paper (Tirana, Albania). Solution containing zero (control), 0.1, 0.2 and 0.4 ppm of AFB1 and the joint concentration of AFB1 together with 0.8, 8 and 800 ppm of Se4+ were added to each plate as shown in Tables 1 and 2. The dishes were allowed to germinate in the dark at 25°C.

caption.p: The effects of different concentrations of Se4+ along with AFB1 on chlorophyll content in Vicia faba and Zea mays. a

fn.p: AFB1: aflatoxin B1; IR: inhibition rate.
aResults are given in milligram per milliliter.

caption.p: The effects of different concentrations of Se4+ along with AFB1 on total protein content in Vicia faba and Zea mays.a

fn.p: AFB1: aflatoxin B1; IR: inhibition rate.
aResults are given in milligram per gram dry.

sec.title: Total protein and chlorophyll content
sec.p: After 7 days, the total chlorophyll content of 20 g of fresh tissue from shoot systems or leaves of maize and vicia bean seedling was estimated spectrophotometrically according to Arnon (1949). Quantitative estimation of total protein in the ground tissue of roots, shoots and leaves of both maize and vicia seedling was estimated according to Lowry et al.( 1951). Each experiment was performed at least three times.

Inhibitory rate (IR, %) was calculated using the following formula
IR=1−x/y×100
where x and y are the average values detected in the control and each sample treated, respectively.

sec.title: DNA isolation and RAPD procedure
sec.p: Genomic DNA was extracted from powdered plant materials using a modified method described by Lin et al. (1999). The control DNA of V. faba and Z. mays was screened for RAPD variation using standard 10-base primers supplied by Operon (Tirana, Albania). Seven of these primers produced amplicons with all the Z. mays, and eight of these primers were selected with V. faba and used for further studies based on the preliminary test results (Tables 3 and 4). After selecting the appropriate primers, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) conditions were prepared.

caption.p: Changes in total bands in control and polymorphic bands and varied bands in different concentrations of Se4+ along with AFBı on maize seed.

fn.p: a:number of new bands; b: disappearance of normal band; a + b: polymorphic band; GTS: genomic template stability; AFB1: aflatoxin B1.

caption.p: Changes in total bands in control and polymorphic bands and varied bands in different concentrations of Se4+ along with AFB1 on vicia seed.

fn.p: a: number of new bands; b: disappearance of normal band; a + b: polymorphic band; GTS: genomic template stability; AFB1: aflatoxin B1.

sec.p: PCR reaction cocktail of 30 μl was prepared as follows: 10× buffer of 3.0 μl, dNTPs (10 mM) of 1.2 μl, magnesium chloride (25 mM) of 1.2 μl, primer (5μM) of 2.0 μl, Taq polymerase (5 units) of 0.4 μl, water of 19.2 μl, sample DNA of 3.0 μl (100 ng/μl).

The thermal cycle was set for 2 min at 95°C; two cycles of 30 s at 95°C, 1 min at 37°C, 2 min at 72°C; two cycles of 30 s at 95°C, 1 min at 35°C, 2 in at 72°C; 41 cycles of 30 s at 94°C, 1 min at 35°C, 2 min at 72°C; followed by a final 5-min extension at 72°C then brought down to 4°C (Taspinar et al., 2011).

sec.title: Electrophoresis
sec.p: The PCR products (27 μl) were mixed with 6× gel loading buffer (3 μl) and loaded onto an agarose (1.5% w/v) gel electrophoresis in 0.5× tris–borate–ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (TBE) buffer and was subjected to electrophoresis at 70 V for 150 min. Gels were stained in EtBr solution (2 μl EtBr/100 ml 1× TBE buffer) for 40 min. The amplified DNA products were detected using the Bio Doc Image Analysis System with Uvisoft analysis package (Cambridge, UK).

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p:
PCR products were scored as presence (1) or absence (0) of the band for each of primer analyzed. Only reproducible bands were scored. Primers that did not show changes in RAPD profile or were too difficult to score were left out in the calculation of genomic template stability (GTS), a qualitative measure reflecting changes in RAPD profiles. GTS (%) was calculated as follows
GTS=1−a/n×100
where a is the average number of polymorphic bands detected in each treated sample and the number of total bands in the control. Polymorphism in RAPD profiles included disappearance of a normal band and appearance of a new PCR band in comparison with control RAPD profiles. All experiments were repeated at least two times.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Analysis of variance (ANOVA) was conducted using a one-way ANOVA test with SPSS 12.0 for Microsoft Windows, and means were compared by Duncan’s multiple range tests at the 0.01 level at confidence.

sec.title: Effect of AFB1 on the levels of total protein and total chlorophyll
sec.p: Significantly, AFB1 decreased the level of total chlorophyll of V. faba and Z. mays when compared with control as seen in Table 1. On the other hand, the level of total chlorophyll decreased progressively with the increasing concentrations of AFB1 (Table 1). Such a decrease was found to be statistically significant (p < 0.01 or p < 0.05). There was a negative correlation between AFB1 concentration and total chlorophyll content of both the crop plants. IRp (%) demonstrates clearly the dose-dependent response of AFB1 that affected the total proteins in both the plants. As it can be seen in Table 2, the protein content decreased with increasing AFB1 concentration (p < 0.01 or p < 0.05). There was a positive correlation between AFB1 concentration and IR (%) of both the plants.

sec.title: Effect of AFB1 on RAPD profiles
sec.p: The produced amplification that was obtained from eight primers of V. faba and seven primers of Z. mays is presented in Tables 3 and 4. The seven random primers generated a total of 53 RAPD bands in Z. mays. The size of the amplicons varied from 50 bp to 1000 bp. Primers OPC05 and OPK06 gave the highest and lowest number of RAPD bands, respectively. However, detected RAPD bands showed a differentiation between AFB1-treated and control DNA samples. Polymorphic bands were detected at each concentration of AFB1 for different primers. Value of polymorphism was P (%) = 54, 67.9 and 77.4%. In all the cases, polymorphisms were due to the loss and gain of the amplified bands in the treated samples in comparison with the control profiles as seen in Table 3. Changes in RAPD pattern were expressed as decreases in GTS. GTS values are shown in Table 3. GTS values indicated a progressive reduction with the ascending of AFB1 concentration.

The eight random primers generated a total of 107 RAPD bands in V. faba. The molecular size of these bands ranged from 50 bp to 1000 bp in the control. Primers OPL15 and OPK13 gave the highest and lowest number of RAPD bands, respectively. With the application of mentioned primers, all samples of AFB1 treatments exhibited alterations in RAPD profiles. RAPD profiles of plant exposure to AFB1 showed a variation in bands, namely loss of normal bands and appearance of new bands compared with normal plant as seen in Table 4. The variation in the RAPD bands increased with the increase in AFB1 concentration. Furthermore, polymorphism values and GTS increased with the increase in AFB1 concentrations. The degree of polymorphism values and GTS were clearly dose dependent.

sec.title: The protective effects of selenium against AFB1-induced inhibition of total protein and chlorophyll levels
sec.p: Tables 1 and 2 summarize the results of different AFB1 concentration on the total protein and chlorophyll levels in V. faba and Z. mays. Total protein and total chlorophyll levels were reduced with the increase in AFB1 concentrations. However, these effects of AFB1 have been seen at higher levels after treatment with different concentrations of Se4+. There was a significant difference between AFB1 and Se4+ (p < 0.01 or p < 0.05). Among all the groups treated with Se4+ and AFB1, especially the 8 ppm concentration of Se4+ increased total protein and chlorophyll concentration. However, the amount of total protein and chlorophyll decreased after treatment with AFB1 and 800 ppm Se4+. Data obtained from Tables 1 and 2 show that the 8 ppm concentration of Se4+ was the most effective dose against total chlorophyll and protein as mentioned above.

sec.title: The protective effects of selenium against AFB1-induced DNA damage using RAPD
sec.p: In total, 15 primers are used to analyze the PCR products in Z. mays and V. faba (Tables 3 and 4). In all the cases, the RAPD profiles of AFB1-exposed seeds were clearly different from the nontreated ones. While polymorphism ratios were increased with the increases in AFB1 concentration, GTS value were decreased. However, these effects of AFB1 seen at higher levels changed after treatment with different concentrations of Se4+, especially the 0.08 and 8 ppm concentrations of Se4+ decreased polymorphism and increased GTS values (Tables 3 and 4).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: A significant decrease in total chlorophyll value and an increase in IR (%) by treatment with different concentrations of AFB1 indicate that AFB1 may inhibit chlorophyll synthesis. Previous studies found that aflatoxins inhibit chlorophyll synthesis, resulting in virescence or albinism in the affected plant with aflatoxins (Agar and Alpsoy, 2005; El-Naghy et al., 1999; Reiss, 1971; Schoental and White, 1965; Sinha and Kumari, 1990). Electron microscopic studies revealed the inhibition of grana formation in chloroplast of maize and oat leaves treated with aflatoxin (El-Naghy et al., 1999; Slowatizky et al., 1969).

The increasing in AFB1 concentration causes a decrease in the protein content of samples (Table 2). Suppression of protein levels by aflatoxins was observed in germinating maize and other crop plants (Agar and Alpsoy, 2005; El-Naghy et al., 1999). According to our data, the most important reason for the decrease in total protein was the inhibition of transcription.

AFB1 significantly decreased the GTS value of V. faba and Z. mays and increased polymorphism when compare with control. The damaging effect of aflatoxins on cells could be attributed to high levels of AFB1 and the fast reaction with some DNA components inside the cells. Previous studies showed that AFB1 could stimulate the release of free radicals, including reactive oxygen species that has oxidative DNA damage (Amstad et al., 1984). While many reactive oxygen species, such as superoxide radical anion, hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides, do not appear to interact with DNA, they are precursors for hydroxyl radical. The reaction of hydroxyl radical with DNA generates a multitude of products, since it attacks sugar, pyrimidines and purines, including guanine residues to form 8-hydroxydeoxyguanosine (8-OHdG). In addition, 8-OHdG predominantly produces transversion mutation (G to T) (Cheng et al., 1992), consistent with a possibility that AFB1-induced oxidative DNA damage.

AFB1 is known to generate the electrophilic intermediate AFB1-8-9-epoxide. Especially, 8,9-exo-epoxide attacks the guanine residues in DNA and an adduct 8,9-dihydro-9-hydroxy (n7guanyl) is formed. As a result of the AFB1-DNA adduct formation, release of AFB1-8-9-dihydrodiol restores the guanylic sites in DNA; depurination, leading to the formation of an apurinic site in DNA; and base-catalyzed hydrolysis during which the imidazole ring opens, forming a stable AFB1-formamidopyr-imidine adduct (Groopman et al., 1981; Hertzog et al., 1982).

As result of the GTS value, transcription and translation are affected. Previous studies found that AFB1 affects GTS, polymorphism value, transcription and translation by binding to DNA in plant and animal organisms (Essigmann et al., 1982; Tripathi and Misra, 1981). This effect of AFB1 on cells decreased after treatment with different concentration of Se4+ + AFB1. With the addition of different concentrations of Se4+, especially, 0.08 and 8 ppm, caused an increase in GTS value, total protein and chlorophyll concentration and a decrease in polymorphism. On the other hand, Se4+ at a concentration of 800 ppm increased the toxic level of AFB1 or Se4+ at a concentration of 800 ppm enhanced the toxicity of AFB1. The protective effect of selenium against AFB1 in animal has also been widely studied. It is recognized as an antimutagenic and anticarcinogenic substance against the cycotoxicty and genotoxicity of AFB1 (Biswas et al., 1997; Oldfield, 1987; Schrauzer, 2000). It was reported that Se4+ supplementation up to dietary levels (1.00 ppm) progressively reduced the acute toxicity of AFB1 in rat and more than 1.00 ppm enhanced the mortality (Agar and Taspinar, 2003). Although selenium has an antimutagenic and anticarcinogenic effect, its optimal concentration is unknown. At high concentrations, it is toxic, mutagenic and carcinogenic; while at low concentrations, it is antimutagenic and anticarcinogenic (Biswas et al., 1997; Oldfield, 1987; Schrauzer, 2000). Selenium of 10 μM concentration was observed to be cytotoxic for human blood lymphocytes (Abul-Hassan et al., 2004). Moreover, the toxicity of elemental selenium was also observed when used in anticancer studies. Even though the recommended daily allowance of selenium by the US Food and Drug Administration is 50 μg/day, cancer preventive dose of selenium is typically 200 μg daily. It is generally accepted that daily intake should not exceed 600 μg (Bahr et al., 1999).

The protective role of Se4+ against this parameter has not been reported. Some studies carried out in plants reveal the capacity of selenium to reduce the toxic effect of aflatoxins (Agar and Alpsoy, 2005; Agar and Taspinar, 2003), but such literature are limited. The antagonistic effect of selenium against AFB1-induced chromosomal aberrations and micronuclei on higher plant has been studied (Geyikoglu and Türkez, 2005). The 8-ppm concentration of Se4+, in particular, has been shown to reduce the micronuclei and chromosomal aberrations effectively. This protective role of Se4+ has been attributed to antioxidative effect of selenium (Agar and Alpsoy, 2005).

In the present study, it has been revealed that Se4+ was an effective inhibitor of AFB1 genotoxicity. These protective effects of Se4+ are probably related to its action on the enzymatic activation system. The protective effects of Se4+ can be attributed primarily to its antioxidant action reported in previous studies in animals and plants (Djanaguiraman et al., 2005; Hartikainen et al., 2000; Seppanen et al., 2003).

In summary, our experimental evidence supports that Se4+ may play an important role against the genotoxicity of AFB1. The protective effect of Se4+ can effectively reduce total protein, total chlorophyll concentration and GTS value.

The protective role of Se4+ was significantly correlated to its concentrations. The literature underlines the observation that selenium in low concentrations may have anticarcinogen effects in animal; whereas in higher concentration, it can be genotoxic and carcinogenic (Biswas et al., 1997; Oldfield, 1987). Also, in plant, at low concentrations, it acts as an antioxidant and stimulates plant growth; whereas at higher concentrations, its acts as a pro-oxidant, reducing plant growth (Srivastava et al., 2009).

Finally, we conclude that Se4+ has suppressed the negative effects of AFB1 on Z. mays and V. faba but an appropriate dose is necessary. Otherwise, inappropriate doses (800 ppm) may cause an unexpected effect. Additional studies are being conducted to confirm this hypothesis.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
